pros:
YOU is a great place to work. I was new to social services, so I really wasn't sure what to expect when I started, but I was pleasantly surprised by how caring, helpful, and friendly all the staff were. I had multiple people on my first day emailing to welcome me to the team and letting me know that I could contact them if I had any questions or needed support, and they weren't just being polite--the team was always willing to answer my questions or help me with whatever situation I had.
I found the management to be supportive, dedicated, and open to change. They understand that it's not always an easy job and strive to assist however they can. When you suggest different ways of doing things, they listen and take your suggestions and ideas into consideration and are willing to implement them to help improve processes and team communication. Overall, I felt supported and listened to while working there.
Finally, they respect your work-life balance by not expecting you to stay late or expecting you to check your phone on nights and weekends, and they are flexible with scheduling (as long as you aren't abusing that flexibility, obviously). I never once felt pressured to check my phone on the weekend or be answering emails before or after regular working hours, which allowed me to unplug and recharge when I wasn't at work.
cons: It is challenging work, which can make it hard some days, but it's also very rewarding.

review_title: Great service to the youth supported, but very little reason to stay for your own professional growth.
pros:
Benefits present
Great service to youth
Be a part of something you can be proud of
Friendly work environment
Executive Director heavily invested in programming
A good place to start off.
Heartfelt attempt to be inclusive
cons:
Organization has no interest in making you a better professional
Opportunity for advancement is not only non-existent, it's discouraged
Average turn around time for most colleagues seems to be around the 3 year mark.
While good to start your career here, management has a difficult time believing in various employees ability to grow and develop
Sometimes takes inclusiveness too far to the point that it will fight discrimination with more discrimination. For example: Employees are not allowed to wish people a "Merry Christmas" because it might offend someone who does not believe in the holiday.

pros: Great place to start a career in social services. Co-workers are easy to get along with. Mission and vision of organization is excellent. Flexible around work-life balance.
cons: Salary is not competitive with other organizations. Very few perks to being an employee outside of feeling good about the work you do.
